author: ralexstokes
content: we actually don't want to introduce this capability for a "light" validator, and i'd say any avenues we find to minimize the validating load should be "upstreamed" into the core consensus protocol where they exist

author: _jmc_.
content:
Is it really a good idea to allow attestation from a light client that doesnt necessarily have staked assets at risk? Seems like a potential attack vector especially if the client is really resource-light (easy and cheap to attack using many clients). 

Levels 1 and 2 make sense to me, but they seem like consecutive stages in a development roadmap rather than a design choice to make at the outset (i.e. develop level 1 light client w client/server model then swap in p2p gossiping later).

author: ralexstokes
content: attestations only make sense in the context of some locked stake (otherwise anyone can go off and attest to whatever valid or invalid chain they desire)

author: ralexstokes
content: the idea of "level 3" is that you are still a bonded validator but you only do the attestation duty

author: ralexstokes
content: assuming you have dropped other data/state necessary to actually produce blocks

author: ralexstokes
content: but this basically makes you a "lazy validator" and for many reasons is not game-theoretically stable wrt a secure consensus protocol ðŸ™‚

author: _jmc_.
content: Ok I see - the l3 light client is a validator with staked eth but reduced validator duties.

author: ralexstokes
content: well more that they just don't do some of them

author: ralexstokes
content: the duties are still there, and/or should be for the "uniformity" reasons i gave in my ethresear.ch response

author: ralexstokes
content: we can actually search for "lazy validator" on ethresear.ch to get a view of the "literature" on this topic, if anyone wants more context

author: ralexstokes
content: and moreover we are trying to mitigate these issues where we can for ethereum validators, e.g. with proofs of custody
